div.sent: We know hens.
However, we need to know about their physiology to rear them profitably.
Different parts of the body of hens bear the marks of their genealogy.
Their output also largely depends on their shape and size.
Like other birds, they have two legs, two wings, and a strong beak.
They have combs on their heads and wattles on the throat.
Some of them have big combs and wattles while some of them have small ones.
The size of their combs varies depending on their species and kinds.
Some of them are single; some of them are double.
Some of them look like peas or roses.
Hens do not give as many eggs as you expect or as much meat as you desire if they are not healthy.
Diseases may spread to all other birds if you fail to identify and cull the sick hens.
Rearing healthy chicks is a pre-condition for profitable poultry farming.
Healthy hens are strong and stout.
Comps on their heads and wattles on their throats look bright red.
Their nose and mouth are clean.
Their stomach is full with food.
Their normal body temperature is 81.6 degrees Celsius, pulse beat per minute 120-170 and breathing 20 - 25 times every minute.
They keep their wings pressed on their body.
Their tails stand upright.
They will crow early in the morning, and always look alert.
They will crow and then make an effort to go away if they come across an enemy.
Go close to the hen.
Observe different parts of the body of the hen.
Compare the parts with the picture of your book.
Discuss with your teacher to understand.
Draw a hen in the practical note book and identify its different parts.
Write down the names of the parts.
